summary: Email correspondence between UK solicitor Jill Greenfield and a NYPD/FBI detective regarding arranging an interview with Greenfield's client, a victim of sexual assault in the UK, in connection with the Epstein investigation. The emails discuss scheduling a call and confirm the client's right to anonymity under UK law.

persons.name: Jill Greenfield
persons.role: Partner at Fieldfisher law firm, legal representative for a victim
persons.context: UK solicitor representing a client who is a victim of sexual assault in the UK, corresponding with US law enforcement to arrange an interview for the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Louise Scott
persons.context: Appears in the Cc line of an email, identified as FBI personnel involved in the correspondence chain.

connections.description: Greenfield is the legal representative for a client who is a victim of sexual assault in the UK and is involved in the Epstein investigation.
Greenfield and Scott are both involved in email correspondence regarding the Epstein investigation and scheduling an interview with Greenfield's client.

events.title: Email coordination for victim interview
events.description: Series of emails between Jill Greenfield and a NYPD/FBI detective to schedule a call and arrange an interview in London with Greenfield's client, a victim in the Epstein case.

locations: Riverbank House, 2 Swan Lane, London EC4R 3TT (Fieldfisher office)
New York, NY (implied location of SDNY prosecutors and NYPD/FBI task force)
keyFacts: Jill Greenfield, a UK solicitor, represents a client who is a victim of sexual assault that occurred in the UK and is relevant to the Epstein investigation.
The client is entitled to automatic anonymity under UK Statute as a victim of sexual assault in the UK and does not waive that right.
US law enforcement (NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force and SDNY prosecutors) are seeking to interview the victim in London.
Emails from late January to early February 2020 show coordination efforts to schedule a call and meeting, with mentions of technical issues with email delivery.
